Award.AwardTitle: ABI: Innovation: Computationally uncovering dynamic transcription factor interactions within and across organisms
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project entails the development of new computational methods to uncover the dynamic variation of transcriptional regulatory networks. While nearly all cells within an organism have the same DNA, they can exhibit very different characteristics as different genes are turned on, or expressed, within them. Transcription factor interactions, comprising regulatory networks, control which genes are expressed, and thus the dynamics of these interactions across cells, conditions and organisms are a critical feature of proper biological functioning. To date, however, most existing knowledge about regulatory networks is static in nature: for nearly all organisms, transcription factor interactions are known under only a small number of conditions of interest. To help fill this gap and begin to uncover the dynamic nature of transcriptional regulatory networks, novel computational approaches will be developed to predict and compare condition-specific transcriptional interactions within an organism and varying transcriptional interactions across organisms. Software for these tasks will be released and made available to the broader scientific community. Additionally, significant new outreach efforts will be undertaken to recruit a diverse group of students to take part in this research.

More specifically, new computational approaches will be developed to uncover and differentially analyze condition-specific and cross-organism variation both in regulatory interactions between transcription factors and their genomic targets, as well as in interactions amongst regulators themselves, as these interactions are a central mechanism by which regulatory specificity is achieved. The approaches will leverage large numbers of transcription factors with known binding specificities, existing chromatin accessibility data across numerous conditions that reveal which portions of a genome are accessible to be bound by transcription factors in those conditions, and comparative analysis of multiple closely related fully sequenced organisms. The results of this research will be disseminated at http://compbio.cs.princeton.edu.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Transcription factors are proteins that bind to specific DNA sequences and regulate when genes are expressed. Transcription factor interactions with DNA are critically important, as they ensure that the right genes are expressed at the right time. Knowledge of transcription factor interactions—and how they change across populations, species, and within a single organism—is critical to understand proper biological functioning and malfunctioning, as is the case in disease.  While significant experimental efforts have determined transcription factor interactions within specific contexts and for specific organisms, computational tools are necessary to obtain a more comprehensive view of these regulatory interactions and how they vary.  This project developed computational methods and infrastructure to predict transcription factor and other protein interactions, as well as to model and analyze the variation of these interactions.

 

Intellectual merit:  We developed structural, domain, and machine learning based approaches for predicting transcription factor DNA-binding specificities and for uncovering the sites within transcription factors and other proteins that participate in interactions.  We developed a new resource based on protein domains that reveals how interactions and specificities vary across organisms and across healthy and disease populations. We developed novel algorithms for inferring the evolutionary history of DNA-binding domains and the transcription factors that contain them, thereby obtaining knowledge about how transcription factor interactions evolve.  We developed  and applied new computational methods for analyzing high-throughput datasets that profile protein-DNA interactions in different contexts.

 

Broader impact: We developed several open source software tools and resource webpages, and made them available to the broader scientific community. We enhanced existing research infrastructure, as other scientists can use our resources for online data exploration and can build upon our codebase. This project involved several educational and outreach activities.  In addition to developing a new undergraduate course, we involved numerous undergraduate and graduate students in research, thereby contributing to their training. We successfully recruited students from groups traditionally under-represented in science, and several of these students went on to graduate studies.  Additionally, the PI and her group gave several scientific talks to elementary and middle school students. 

 


Last Modified: 09/18/2020
Modified by: Mona Singh
